feature: Observation: Strong positive SHAP attribution concentrated at the lowest frequency rows (near 0–0.06 Hz) from roughly time step 26 to 65 (major red block on the heatmap). -> Implication: The classifier is relying on a slow, large-scale upward trend (low-frequency / DC-like component) in this middle window to support the Mirage label. This corresponds in the time series to a rise from a local trough (approximately -1.4 at t≈25) up to a moderate positive value (≈+0.6 to +0.8 around t≈50–65). The change is gradual and smooth (average slope ≈ +0.05–0.07 units per time step), indicating that broad contour/shape (large-scale curvature) rather than sharp local detail is important here.

Observation: Within the 26–65 window the time series substructure is: a local minimum at ~t=25 (amplitude ≈ -1.4), a small rebound bump near t≈30 (amplitude ≈ -1.0), then a sustained monotonic rise to positive values by t≈45–52 and peaking near t≈60 (amplitude ≈ +0.6–0.8). Volatility in this interval is low (no high-frequency oscillation), with the signal dominated by a single slow upward movement. -> Implication: The low volatility and single-sweep shape (trough → slow rise → plateau/peak) produce concentrated low-frequency spectral energy and are interpreted by the model as a positive cue for label 0 (Mirage).

Observation: Smaller, higher-frequency local fluctuations (small wiggles of amplitude ≈0.1–0.3) are visible around t≈26–35 and t≈55–65. The STFT shows these are low-power compared with the DC/very-low-frequency band. SHAP on those higher-frequency bands is neutral to slightly negative in parts (pale/blueish elsewhere). -> Implication: These small ripples are not the main driver for the positive classification; rather, their low magnitude and low spectral power means they do not override the positive contribution of the dominant low-frequency trend.

Observation: Another area of positive SHAP at low frequencies appears earlier (t≈0–5) and later at t≈90–104 but with lower intensity than the 26–65 block. In the signal these correspond to the high positive start (t≈0 value ≈+2.4) and a mid/late small positive hump (t≈90 value ≈+1.2). -> Implication: The classifier also considers large positive offsets at the beginning and the mid-late positive hump as supporting evidence; consistent pattern of large-scale positive lobes separated by troughs appears to match the Mirage signature the model learned.

Observation: Strong negative SHAP (blue) in some mid-to-higher frequency rows during other time ranges (notably around mid frequencies) while low-frequency rows are red. The STFT shows relatively little energy at mid-to-high frequencies overall. -> Implication: The model penalizes (negative contribution) mid/high-frequency content — i.e., sharp, localized contour changes — so the absence (or low power) of such sharp features increases probability of Mirage. Thus the classification is driven positively by smooth, large-scale shape and negatively by jagged/high-frequency detail.

Observation: The rise from the trough at t≈25 to the peak at t≈75 (if considered globally) corresponds to ~2.9–3.2 units of amplitude change over ≈50 time steps (average slope ≈ +0.06 per step). In contrast, the later descent from t≈95 to t≈115 is faster (≈ -1.9 over 15 steps ≈ -0.12 per step) and the SHAP map gives less consistent positive attribution to that faster drop. -> Implication: The classifier prefers slow, smooth transitions (positive attribution) over rapid, steep transitions (which are not strongly positively attributed). This reinforces that slow-scale contour features are diagnostic of the Mirage class in this dataset.

Observation: Time–frequency view (STFT) shows most signal energy concentrated at the very low frequency bins across the sample, with peaks of low-frequency energy aligned with the SHAP-positive time windows (start, middle 26–65, and some mid-late times). -> Implication: Both the model explanation (SHAP) and the spectral decomposition agree that low-frequency components (broad contour features) are the salient drivers for classification; the model’s internal representation is focusing on these slow components to assign label 0.

Observation: Strong positive SHAP concentration at low frequencies centered roughly on time steps 13–30 (most intense around 20–26). In the time series this corresponds to a steep, large-amplitude downward movement from about +2.3 (t≈0) through ~0 (t≈13) to a local minimum ≈-1.5 (t≈26–30). The STFT shows high energy at the lowest frequency band in this same time range. -> Implication: This broad, low-frequency descending curvature (a long-wavelength shape change) is an important positive cue for the classifier toward label 0. In shape terms it likely encodes a large-scale contour feature (e.g., a major fuselage/leading-edge curvature) that is characteristic of the Mirage class.

Observation: Positive SHAP signal (low-frequency band) around time steps ~48–56. In the raw signal this maps to a smooth upward ramp from about -1.2 (t≈40) to a local positive peak ≈+0.7 (t≈52–56). Volatility is low (gradual rise), the change rate is moderate (~+0.12 to +0.14 units per time step), and STFT shows elevated energy at the lowest frequency with little high-frequency content. -> Implication: A mid-sequence broad upward bulge (gentle convexity) contributes positively to the Mirage prediction — the classifier is using this smooth mid-contour bulge as supporting evidence.

Observation: Positive SHAP area (low freq) extending across roughly time steps 64–92 with the strongest contributions near 72–84. The time series in this window shows a rise from ~-0.4 (t≈66) up to a pronounced local peak ≈+1.6–1.8 (t≈80–84) followed by a visible drop toward ~-0.4 (t≈96). The structure is a prominent broad peak (low volatility within the rise and fall, i.e., dominated by low-frequency content) as confirmed by STFT energy concentrated in the lowest frequency band. -> Implication: This large, smooth central peak is another key positive feature the model relies on — it likely corresponds to a major wing or canopy contour segment distinctive for the Mirage shape.

Observation: The SHAP map shows weaker (near-white) or slightly negative contributions at some times immediately following the large peak (around t≈88–100) and at mid frequencies. The series here has a relatively fast downward slope from the large peak to a small rebound at t≈102 (small transient). STFT indicates some slight mid-frequency energy during the rapid change. -> Implication: These faster transitional components slightly reduce the Mirage prediction (negative SHAP) — localized sharper changes (higher relative frequency) are less typical of the class or reduce confidence compared with the broad features.

Observation: Later in the sequence (t≈104–120) the time series drops to another deep trough around -1.3 (t≈116) with moderate slope and modest small-scale wiggles (higher-frequency small oscillations). SHAP in these higher-frequency bands is neutral-to-slightly-positive at lowest frequencies but not strongly red. -> Implication: The existence of a second trough helps define the overall multi-lobe contour, but because it contains more small-scale variability it contributes less strongly (or more ambiguously) than the earlier broad peaks and troughs.

Observation: Final window (t≈120–143) shows a sustained, relatively smooth rise from ≈-1.35 to ≈+2.35 (end), fastest average upward rate among later ramps (~+0.16 units/step). STFT shows low-frequency energy reappearing toward the end, and SHAP shows modest positive contribution at low frequency near the sequence end. -> Implication: This strong low-frequency terminal rise reinforces the positive class evidence — a large final convex contour segment is consistent with Mirage and increases classifier score.
pattern: The feature pattern of Sample 100 is: (1) Early high positive baseline (t≈0, amplitude ≈+2.4) — a strong large-scale positive lobe that contributes positively to the label; (2) Rapid descent to a pronounced trough (t≈25, amplitude ≈-1.4) followed by a smooth, low-volatility upward sweep from t≈26 to t≈65 (amplitude change ≈+1.9 to +2.2, average slope ≈+0.05–0.07) — this mid-window slow-rise is the strongest positive driver for Mirage according to SHAP and STFT (dominant low-frequency energy); (3) A second larger positive peak near t≈70–80 (amplitude ≈+1.6–1.8) followed by another smoother descent to a trough near t≈115 (amplitude ≈-1.3 to -1.4) and a final rise to a large positive value at the end (t≈143, amplitude ≈+2.4). Overall the series is dominated by 2–3 slow undulations (low-frequency cycles), low local volatility (few high-frequency spikes), and asymmetric rates (the downward transitions can be steeper than the upward ones). The classifier attributes positive importance to the slow/low-frequency lobes (especially the mid-window trough→rise segment) and negative or neutral importance to mid/high-frequency content — indicating the label decision is based on large-scale smooth contour features rather than sharp local details.

Overall characterization: The sample is dominated by large low-frequency components (broad peaks and troughs) that define three main large-scale structures across the sequence: an early large descent (t≈0–30), a mid-section of alternating broad rise/peak and fall (t≈40–100), and a strong final broad rise (t≈120–143).

Trend & amplitude: Global swings are large (range ≈ -1.6 to +2.4). There is no stationary mean: the series begins at a high positive value, declines to a deep trough, recovers to two separate broad peaks, then falls and finally rises to the overall end maximum. Peak magnitudes at early and final edges are comparable (~+2.3), while interior peaks are smaller (~+0.7 and ~+1.6).

Frequency & volatility: Energy concentrates in the lowest frequency band (STFT bright at the lowest frequencies during key windows). Volatility is generally low within these broad events (smooth ramps), with occasional localized higher-frequency variability during transitions and near troughs. Sharp, high-frequency components are weak and contribute little positive SHAP weight.

Temporal dependence & substructure: Longer ramps (t≈0–30 and t≈120–143) show sustained monotonic change; mid-sequence behavior is composite — a moderate upward ramp, a shallow trough, then a pronounced central peak and descent. The classifier’s positive evidence correlates with the timing and amplitude of these broad convex/concave segments (low-frequency substructures), indicating a dependence on the sequence and ordering of large-scale contour features rather than on isolated narrow spikes.

Classification basis (dataset context): Given this dataset represents top-view plane contours, the model appears to use the presence, relative timing, and amplitude of broad, smooth contour segments (the large low-frequency rises/falls corresponding to fuselage and wing curvature) as discriminative features for label 0 (Mirage). The SHAP map shows the classifier assigns strongest positive weight to large-scale, low-frequency bulges/troughs at t≈13–30, t≈48–56 and t≈64–92 which together form a signature consistent with the Mirage contour.

feature: Observation: Strong positive SHAP activation is concentrated in the lowest frequency rows (near 0 Hz) between approximately time steps 39 and 95. In the raw trace this interval begins with a zero crossing at ~38, a modest local peak around 48–55 (~+0.6 to +0.8), a pronounced main peak about 72–78 (≈+1.8 to +1.95), followed by a relatively fast decline to a trough near 86–90 (≈-1.1 to -1.3) and a small rebound by ~95 (≈+0.5). -> Implication: The classifier strongly relies on a slow, large-amplitude oscillation (low-frequency, broad-scale shape) in the mid-segment. The pattern of a gradual build-up to a large positive bulge and a faster fall to a trough is a distinctive global shape feature that increases probability for label 1.

Observation: The mid-segment low-frequency cycle is asymmetric: rise from ~38 to ~75 is gradual (≈ +0.05 normalized units per time step averaged), whereas the decline from ~75 to ~88 is much steeper (≈ -0.24 units/step averaged). The amplitude swing across this cycle is about 3.0–3.2 normalized units (from trough to peak). -> Implication: The classifier is sensitive not only to the presence of a slow cycle but to its temporal asymmetry (slower build vs. faster decay). This asymmetry in the mid window is a discriminative substructure for label 1.

Observation: STFT (time–frequency image) shows most energy concentrated in the lowest frequency bins during the same mid-window (39–95). Higher-frequency bands in this interval are comparatively weak. -> Implication: The model attribution to the mid-window comes from true low-frequency content (broad shape), confirming the SHAP red band corresponds to slow structural components rather than short, noisy fluctuations.

Observation: A secondary positive SHAP region (weaker red) appears in the late segment around time steps ≈118–144. The raw series shows a sharp upward trend there: from about -1.4 at ~118 to about +2.5 at 144 (≈ +4.0 units over ~26 steps; average slope ≈ +0.15 units/step). STFT shows moderate low-frequency energy in this late window too. -> Implication: A strong late slow upward trend (large low-frequency component) also contributes positively to the Eurofighter classification. The classifier treats late, sustained rises as supporting evidence.

Observation: Early time (0–13) shows some low-frequency energy in STFT and a faint positive SHAP signal at the very lowest frequency bin, but the SHAP magnitude is much smaller than mid- and late-windows. The raw trace there is a smooth monotonic decline from ~+2.6 to ~0.0. -> Implication: Early broad-scale level (high starting value followed by smooth downward trend) provides minor positive evidence, but is not the dominant discriminative feature for label 1.

Observation: The SHAP heatmap shows slight negative (blue) values in some mid-to-higher frequency rows across some columns (e.g., weak blue patches around 0.08–0.25 frequency bins in parts of the mid window). The raw trace displays small wiggles/short fluctuations superimposed on the large cycle. -> Implication: Faster, higher-frequency oscillations (small-scale jitter) reduce the classifier's support for label 1; the model prefers smooth, low-frequency morphology over noisy/high-frequency substructure for this class.

Observation: The mid-window (39–95) contains clear substructure: an initial small hump (~48–55), the dominant hump (~72–78), and a following trough (~86–90). These sub-peaks are separated by tens of steps (i.e., low temporal frequency). -> Implication: The classifier appears to use the presence and relative timing of these sub-peaks (their spacing and amplitudes) as part of the class signature (a multi-stage broad curvature pattern typical of label 1).

Observation: Temporal dependence: the zero crossing near ~38 consistently precedes the large mid-cycle peak and appears to be a systematic anchor point (local phase reset) before the discriminative bulge. -> Implication: The model likely learns phase/sequence information (the order: crossing → modest hump → major hump → sharp fall) as part of the Eurofighter signature rather than treating all time points independently.

Observation: SHAP heatmap shows a strong, concentrated positive attribution (deep red) in the lowest frequency band (near 0 Hz) approximately between time steps 39 and 96 (most intense ~52–91). -> Implication: The model is relying on coarse, low‑frequency (large‑scale) signal structure in the mid segment of the series to push the prediction toward label 1 (Eurofighter). This is not a fine high‑frequency spike but a broad shape / slow oscillation that the classifier finds characteristic.

Observation: On the time series plot the same 39–96 window contains two broad low‑frequency lobes: (a) a rise from around 0 at ~39 to a local peak ≈ +0.7–0.9 at ~48–52, followed by a fall to a trough ≈ -1.0 around ~60–66; (b) a larger rise thereafter to a major peak ≈ +1.6–1.9 around ~72–76 and then a subsequent drop to ≈ -0.9 by ~85–92. Peak‑to‑trough amplitudes in this window cover roughly 2.5–3.0 units. -> Implication: The classifier favors the presence of this two‑cycle, asymmetric oscillatory substructure (a smaller positive hump then a larger positive hump) in the mid region; the relative heights and the sequence (smaller positive hump → trough → larger positive hump → trough) are informative features for label 1.

Observation: Rate of change within the mid segment: the larger positive ascent (from trough ~-1.0 to peak ~+1.8) occurs over roughly 10–15 time steps (moderate slope), while the earlier small rise is gentler. STFT shows most energy for these events at very low frequencies. -> Implication: The discriminative signature is a slow but relatively brisk upward transition (a low‑frequency transient with moderate slope), not abrupt spikes; the change‑rate pattern (gentle small hump then quicker larger ascent) is used by the model as a distinguishing temporal dynamic.

Observation: STFT time–frequency image shows concentrated spectral magnitude at the lowest frequency bins (bottom rows) during the mid time window and relatively little energy at higher frequencies across the series. -> Implication: The predictive signal is dominated by long‑period components (global contour/shape scale) rather than short‑period oscillations or noise. This confirms the SHAP attribution to low frequencies and indicates the classifier extracts coarse shape information encoded in slow variations.

Observation: Early segment (time steps 0–30) exhibits a monotonic decline from ≈ +2.5 down to ≈ -1.6 (large amplitude change) but the SHAP heatmap there is neutral-to-slightly negative (no strong red). -> Implication: Although large amplitude, the early declining trend is not positively associated with label 1 — it may be common across multiple classes or actually counter‑indicative for Eurofighter. The model therefore discounts early large baseline shifts and emphasizes mid‑segment pattern instead.

Observation: Late segment (time steps ~120–143) shows a strong rising trend back to ≈ +2.5, yet SHAP shows little or no positive attribution in that region. -> Implication: Late global amplitude increases are not decisive for the Eurofighter label; the model’s decision hinges on the mid‑segment low‑frequency pattern rather than terminal amplitude extremes.

Observation: Local volatility: within the mid region the signal exhibits moderate volatility (one smaller hump and one larger hump separated by troughs), whereas higher frequency, small amplitude oscillations elsewhere are weak in both STFT and SHAP. -> Implication: The classifier prefers moderate, structured volatility at long timescales (ordered lobes) as discriminative, while random small oscillations and high‑frequency noise are neither emphasized nor helpful for classification.

Observation: Spatial/temporal ordering of substructures: the sequence smaller positive hump → trough → larger positive hump occurs within ~39–80 and is temporally ordered (the larger hump follows the smaller one). -> Implication: The model appears sensitive not only to amplitude and frequency content but to the ordering and relative sizing of these substructures; this sequence is likely a learned signature for Eurofighter contours in this dataset.
pattern: Overall pattern of Sample 33 (label 1): Three broad sequential features dominate the 144-point trace: (1) Early high-level smooth descent (0–25): a monotonic decline from a high starting value to a deep early trough; (2) Dominant mid-frequency/low-frequency asymmetric cycle (≈39–95): a slow, large-amplitude oscillation with a gradual rise (small hump at ~50 then main peak at ~75) and a faster fall into a trough near ~88 — this band contains the strongest low-frequency energy and the largest positive SHAP attribution; (3) Late pronounced upward trend (≈118–144): a relatively rapid, sustained rise from a negative value to a high positive value. Frequency content is concentrated at the very low end (broad, slow components); higher-frequency, small-scale fluctuations are weak and tend to reduce label 1 probability. Temporally, these features are ordered and phase-linked (zero crossing near ~38 reliably precedes the discriminative mid-cycle), so the classifier leverages both amplitude/shape and their sequential arrangement to decide label 1.

Classification rationale tied to dataset: Given the dataset context (plane contour-derived 1D signatures), the model favors sustained, global curvature patterns (broad, low-frequency bulges and asymmetries) located in the mid-to-late temporal regions of the signature for Eurofighter (label 1). The SHAP map shows that those broad low-frequency bulges (especially the large asymmetric mid-cycle and the late rise) are the primary evidence driving the prediction toward label 1, whereas short, high-frequency jitter works against that label.

The feature pattern of Sample 88 (label 1, Eurofighter) is: (1) Mid‑segment low‑frequency oscillatory pattern (time ~39–96): two ordered cycles — a smaller positive lobe at ~39–52 (amplitude ≈ +0.7–0.9) followed by a trough (~60–66, ≈ -1.0) and then a larger positive lobe peaking at ~72–76 (amplitude ≈ +1.6–1.9) then returning to negative by ~85–92. This pattern carries the strongest positive attribution. + (2) Low spectral content (dominant energy in the lowest frequency bins across the mid window) indicating coarse/long‑period structure rather than high‑frequency detail. + (3) Early decline (time 0–30) and late rise (time 120–143) are large amplitude but show little positive attribution (neutral/negative SHAP), meaning they are not discriminative for label 1 here. + (4) Overall temporal dependence: the classifier relies on ordered, moderate‑volatility, low‑frequency substructures in the middle of the series (the number, relative amplitude and ordering of the lobes) as the primary cue for assigning this sample to the Eurofighter class.

feature: Observation (t ≈ 0–15) -> The series begins at a large positive value (~+2.6) and falls nearly monotonically to around 0 over the first ~13–15 steps. This is a high-amplitude, low-frequency downward swing with a large net change (≈ -2.5 to -3.0) and a steep negative slope (fast change rate for this series). STFT: strong energy concentrated at the lowest frequency bins during this interval. SHAP: the same interval shows red (positive) attribution concentrated at the lowest frequencies. -> Implication: this broad, slow downward ramp early in the sequence is an important discriminative baseline feature the model uses (low-frequency shape/curvature information). The model treats a large early decline in the contour signal as evidence toward label 2.

Observation (t ≈ 13–35) -> Immediately following the early fall, the signal reaches a pronounced negative trough centered around t ≈ 25–30 (minimum ≈ -1.5 to -1.7). The trough is wide (sustained over ~10–15 steps), smooth (low volatility inside the trough), and represents a large-scale negative excursion of the signal. STFT: persistent low-frequency magnitude across this trough. SHAP: red attribution overlaps the leading portion of this trough (especially 13–26) at lowest frequencies. -> Implication: the presence of a deep, sustained negative deflection (a slow valley) is treated as a positive indicator for label 2, i.e., the classifier relies on this large-scale valley as part of the F-14 (wings closed) signature.

Observation (t ≈ 36–52) -> After the trough, the series rises smoothly to a moderate positive local peak around t ≈ 45–52 (peak ≈ +0.6–0.8). This is a lower-amplitude, low-frequency hump spanning ~10–16 steps, with modest slope and little high-frequency jitter. STFT: modest low-frequency energy and slight presence of low–mid frequencies. SHAP: mild positive attribution at low frequencies in this interval. -> Implication: this mid-segment upward hump is a secondary positive cue; the classifier combines it with earlier trough/peak structure to recognize the overall contour pattern of the class.

Observation (t ≈ 65–91, strongest at 78–91) -> The middle–late segment contains another smooth positive oscillation: a local rise around t ≈ 65–91 reaching ≈ +0.5–0.7 and lasting ~15–25 steps. The oscillation is low-frequency, relatively stable (low volatility), and resembles the earlier hump in shape but shifted later in time. STFT: increased energy at the lowest frequency bins during these times. SHAP: distinct red (strong positive attribution) concentrated in the bottom frequency rows for t ≈ 78–91. -> Implication: the repetition of a similar slow positive hump at this precise time window is a key reinforcing feature; the classifier uses the occurrence and timing of this hump (not just its existence) to favor label 2.

Observation (t ≈ 100–125, strongest ≈ 104–120) -> A second large negative trough occurs here: the signal declines from near zero to a deep trough around t ≈ 110–120 (min ≈ -1.4 to -1.6) and then begins recovery. This trough is wide and smooth (sustained low-frequency negative excursion over ~15–20 steps). STFT: pronounced low-frequency energy centered on this interval. SHAP: the strongest red attribution is concentrated across the lowest-frequency bins during t ≈ 104–130. -> Implication: this deep, late trough (and its recovery) is one of the strongest contributors to the classification — the model detects this slow, high-amplitude valley as a hallmark of the label-2 contour.

Observation (t ≈ 125–143) -> From about t ≈ 125 onward the series shows a rapid, large-amplitude upward recovery and final rise, ending at ≈ +2.6 by t = 143. This final segment has a high positive slope (fast change relative to local baseline) and results in a large positive endpoint. STFT: low-frequency content remains strong; SHAP: moderate positive attribution at lowest frequencies near the end. -> Implication: the late, sharp upward swing culminating in a high positive endpoint acts as an additional positive signal for the model, reinforcing the class decision when combined temporally with the earlier trough/rise pattern.

Observation (frequency-domain summary across red areas) -> SHAP red attributions are almost entirely concentrated in the bottom frequency rows (very low frequencies) and are localized to three main time blocks (≈13–26, ≈78–91, ≈104–130). The STFT also shows the largest magnitudes at these same low frequencies and time blocks. -> Implication: the classifier's decision for this sample relies primarily on slow, large-scale (low-frequency) components of the contour signal occurring at specific time positions rather than on short, high-frequency fluctuations. In other words, timing and shape of broad humps/troughs across the sequence are the decisive cues.
pattern: Overall pattern of Sample 75 (Label 2): Dominant low-frequency, multi-stage oscillatory shape composed of (1) an early high positive value followed by a steep downward transition into a wide negative trough (t ≈ 0–35) (large amplitude change, high initial slope, low volatility inside trough) + (2) a moderate mid-sequence positive hump (t ≈ 36–52) (smooth upward curvature, modest amplitude) + (3) a later positive hump (t ≈ 65–91) (similar shape to the mid hump, reinforcing) + (4) a pronounced late negative trough and recovery (t ≈ 100–125) followed by a rapid final rise to a large positive endpoint (t ≈ 125–143).

Temporal dependence and periodicity: The sample shows slow quasi-periodic behaviour — roughly two full large-scale oscillation half-cycles across the 144 points (i.e., broad trough–peak–trough–peak structure). Features occur at consistent, separated time windows (early, mid, late) rather than being random; the classifier appears to use the sequence and timing of those low-frequency humps/troughs together (temporal patterning) to make a label decision.

Volatility and substructure: Local volatility is low within the broad humps and troughs (smooth shapes), while transitions between them (start and end segments) have higher instantaneous slopes. Small higher-frequency wiggles are present but have low STFT magnitude and low SHAP attribution — they are not primary drivers of classification.

Classifier basis for label 2: SHAP and STFT indicate the model places greatest importance on low-frequency, large-amplitude shape events occurring at the three highlighted windows (≈13–26, ≈78–91, ≈104–130). Combining these slow humps/troughs in the observed temporal order matches the prototypical contour temporal signature the model learned for F-14 (wings closed) from training examples; thus the model classifies this sample as label 2 largely on the basis of those temporally aligned low-frequency features.

feature: Observation: Strong low-frequency negative swing between approx. t=10 and t=26 (SHAP red concentrated in the lowest frequency rows at these time steps). The numeric trace falls from about +2.3 (t≈0) through zero near t≈12 to a local trough ≈ -1.5 around t≈18–20 (net change ≈ -4.0 over ~18 steps, average slope ≈ -0.22 units/step). Volatility during the descent is low (smooth, monotonic drop) and the STFT shows energy concentrated in the lowest frequency band during this window. -> Implication: A large, smooth, low-frequency downward deflection is a discriminative macro-structure that contributes positively to the sample being labeled as F-14 (wings opened). The classifier is using this extended slow change (shape-scale feature) rather than small rapid noise to support the class.

Observation: Pronounced deep trough centered near t≈48–54 (plot minimum ≈ -2.0 at ~t=50). This is a broad, low-frequency negative excursion (width ≈ 8–12 steps), again with STFT energy at low frequencies and corresponding small-to-moderate positive SHAP values in the same low-frequency rows. -> Implication: Another large-scale negative lobe (deeper than the earlier trough) provides additional positive evidence for the same class; the model appears to recognize multiple separated low-frequency negative deflections as characteristic for this label.

Observation: Mid-sequence zone from roughly t≈60 to t≈85 shows small-amplitude, higher-frequency oscillations (amplitudes ≈ ±0.2–0.6), quickly alternating around 0. The SHAP map in these columns is mostly neutral-to-light (mixed) and the STFT shows modest energy in higher frequency rows relative to the large events. -> Implication: These higher-frequency, low-amplitude fluctuations are not the primary discriminative signals; they act as local detail (texture) but carry weak attribution toward the class.

Observation: Prominent positive peak and rapid rise between t≈92 and t≈106 (rise from roughly -1.8 to ≈ +1.4, net change ≈ +3.2 over ≈14 steps, average slope ≈ +0.23 units/step). SHAP bottom-frequency rows in this time block are strongly red and STFT again shows concentrated low-frequency energy. -> Implication: A rapid, large-scale upward swing (followed by a fall) is strongly positively attributed to the class. The classifier uses both the magnitude and the sign of this low-frequency pulse (rise + peak) as a cue.

Observation: End-segment rise from about t≈130 to t=143: the trace climbs from approximately 0 (slightly negative) to a final peak ≈ +2.4 (sustained increase over the last ~14 steps). The SHAP heatmap shows low-frequency rows with positive contributions here as well; the STFT displays increased low-frequency magnitude at the end. -> Implication: The final sustained increase is another supporting low-frequency feature. The classifier treats multiple separated slow rises (and falls) across the sequence as reinforcing evidence for the F-14 wings-open shape.

Observation: Frequency attribution (from STFT + SHAP): almost all strongly positive SHAP regions align with the lowest-frequency STFT rows (closest to 0 Hz). Higher-frequency rows either show weak STFT energy or mixed/neutral SHAP colors. -> Implication: The model’s decisions are driven primarily by large-scale, slow-varying waveform components (low-frequency structure) rather than short, high-frequency details. This indicates the classifier encodes global contour-scale features (broad lobes and slow swings) for this shape class.
pattern: Overall description: The time series is dominated by a small number (3–4) of large, slow oscillations (low-frequency components) across the 144 time points, interleaved with short windows of higher-frequency, low-amplitude wiggles. Major low-frequency events occur early (t≈10–26, downward), mid (t≈46–54, deep trough), a late-mid positive pulse (t≈92–106), and a final sustained rise (t≈130–143).

Periodicity and frequency content: The signal is quasi-periodic at a low fundamental frequency (STFT energy concentrated in the bottom frequency band). The sequence shows several cycles of broad peaks/troughs rather than rapid repeated cycles; this yields dominant low-frequency power with intermittent bursts in time that correspond to the major waveform lobes.

Volatility and local structure: Volatility is heterogeneous: low during the large slow swings (smooth monotonic rises/falls) and higher during middle windows (t≈60–85) where small-amplitude, faster oscillations appear. Change rates for main events are substantial (typical slopes for large swings ≈ 0.18–0.25 units/step), while local oscillations have much smaller instantaneous rates.

Temporal dependence and combination: The classifier attributes positive evidence to multiple separated low-frequency events (early negative swing + mid/late positive pulses + final rise). These events combine additively in the model’s attribution (SHAP) — multiple spatially/temporally separated low-frequency lobes strengthen the decision. The interleaving small oscillations have limited effect and serve as secondary texture.

Classification basis relative to dataset: Given the dataset background (top-contour-derived features of different fighter models and the presence of a distinctive 'wings-open' configuration), the model appears to rely on large-scale, low-frequency waveform motifs (broad, sustained positive and negative lobes at specific time locations) as signatures of the F-14 wings-open class. The SHAP map shows consistent positive contributions at the lowest-frequency band whenever such lobes occur, indicating that global contour-scale patterns (not high-frequency details) are the primary basis for class assignment.

feature: Observation -> Implication: Strong low-frequency, large-amplitude rising bump between ~t=52 and t=71 (peak). In the raw trace the value rises from about -0.9 at t≈52 to a peak ≈+2.6 at t≈70 (Δ≈3.5). This is a smooth, mostly monotonic increase (low local volatility) with an average slope ≈0.19 units/time-step and some acceleration in the final ~8–12 steps. Implication: the classifier strongly favors this slowly varying, high-magnitude positive deflection as evidence for label 4 (Harrier).

Observation -> Implication: Preceding shallow valley/plateau from ~t=38 to t=52. The signal sits slightly below zero (≈ -0.2 down to ≈ -0.9) with small oscillations before the big rise. Implication: this local trough creates a clear contrast (valley → large rise) that enhances the low-frequency energy of the subsequent upward segment and increases its discriminative power.

Observation -> Implication: Concentrated STFT energy at the lowest frequency bins during the mid-segment (roughly t≈39–78). The STFT image shows the highest magnitude in the bottom-most frequency rows over the same time window where SHAP is positive. Implication: the model is responding to a DC/slow-wave feature (a broad shape change) rather than fast oscillatory detail — i.e. a broad contour bulge in the underlying shape/time-series representation.

Observation -> Implication: SHAP heatmap shows the largest positive attribution localized to the lowest-frequency components in the mid time window (strong red block centered roughly on t≈52–65). Implication: the classifier’s positive evidence for Harrier primarily comes from the presence of that low-frequency, high-magnitude mid-segment feature (not high-frequency noise or brief spikes).

Observation -> Implication: Local substructure — a short plateau/inflection near t≈39–45 followed by a small negative dip into the trough (~t=52) then a pronounced ascent. The ascent itself is smooth and single-peaked (no high-frequency ripples). Implication: the clean single-peaked substructure is likely a stable, repeatable descriptor the model learned (consistent inter-class discriminant) and therefore yields strong positive SHAP values.

Observation -> Implication: End-of-series recovery (t≈130–143) is a moderate positive rise (≈+0.5→+1.2) but with weaker STFT magnitude and mostly neutral-to-light-red SHAP. Implication: later smaller rises resemble the mid bump in sign but lack amplitude and low-frequency energy; they provide only weak supporting evidence compared with the central large bump.

Observation -> Implication: Negative-contributing regions (light blue in other parts of SHAP) align with moderate negative troughs (for example around t≈16–26 and again around t≈104–117). Implication: these negative troughs decrease the model’s confidence in label 4 when present alone; but when followed by the large mid bump their negative contribution is outweighed by the strong positive mid-frequency/DC feature.

Observation -> Implication: Volatility profile — the series is dominated by slow, smooth swings (low volatility except during transition windows). STFT confirms low-frequency dominance across most of the timeline, with energy spikes concentrated where the big amplitude changes occur. Implication: classification relies on the slow, global outline of the series (broad bumps and dips) rather than transient high-frequency fluctuations.

Observation: Strong positive SHAP concentration at low frequencies between time steps ~39–70 (bright red block at the bottom rows of the SHAP heatmap). Implication: The classifier attributes this time window (39–70) as the single most important contributor to predicting label 4 (Harrier); this contribution comes from a slowly varying, large-amplitude structure in the signal (a low-frequency, global contour feature).

Observation: In the raw plot the same window (approx. t=45 → t=65) contains a smooth, large upward hump rising from ~0.5 to a peak ≈ 2.6 (amplitude change ≈ +2.1) then beginning a faster descent after the peak. Implication: The event is a broad, asymmetric peak (slow rise over ~20 steps, sharper fall over ~10–15 steps). The positive SHAP values align with the hump’s peak, meaning the presence and amplitude of this hump strongly increase the model’s confidence for label 4.

Observation: STFT shows elevated energy confined to the lowest frequency bins during t≈39–70 and little energy at higher frequencies for that window. Implication: The hump is low-frequency (a broad geometric feature of the contour) rather than a high-frequency edge or noise; the model uses this low-frequency component to recognize a large-scale shape attribute of the Harrier contour.

Observation: Around t≈0–18 the series falls from ~1.0 down to a trough near −1.9 (sharp decline, roughly −2.9 total change over ~14 steps) and the SHAP heatmap shows weak-to-moderate positive contributions at low frequency there as well. Implication: A pronounced early negative trough (sharp decline then partial recovery) is also considered helpful by the model — likely representing a complementary contour indentation (e.g., wing or notch) that jointly with the mid-hump supports the Harrier label.

Observation: After the main hump, between t≈70–105 the signal falls through zero to a modest negative valley around t≈104–110 (amplitude roughly −1.8) and the SHAP map in that region is mostly neutral to slightly negative. Implication: This descending portion contributes less positively (or slightly negatively) to the Harrier classification; the model expects the prominent positive hump, while the post-peak descent/valley is not a strong positive cue and may slightly reduce confidence.

Observation: Late in the series (t≈117–143) the time series trends upward from roughly −1.8 to ~1.0 with moderate volatility and the SHAP map shows small positive contributions at low frequency near the end. Implication: A late positive rise (smaller and more volatile than the main hump) provides additional supportive evidence for the class but is secondary to the main mid-segment hump.

Observation: Substructure of the main hump is asymmetric: the rise (≈t=45→65) is more gradual than the fall (≈t=65→78), and STFT during the rise shows persistent low-frequency energy while no new high-frequency bands appear. Implication: The classifier appears sensitive to the asymmetry (slow rise + quicker drop) as a distinctive geometric signature (e.g., a prominent fuselage section followed by a sharper transition) rather than to symmetric or oscillatory features.

Observation: Across the whole series most SHAP activity is concentrated in the lowest frequency bins (rows nearest zero frequency) with limited high-frequency SHAP activation. Implication: The model is basing decisions primarily on coarse/large-scale contour features (global shape components) rather than fine-grained high-frequency textures or noise.
pattern: Overall pattern of Sample 66 (label 4 - Harrier):

Feature 1 (early segment, t≈0–26): small-magnitude positive start followed by a pronounced negative trough (t≈16–26) reaching ≈ -1.9. Manifestation: moderate amplitude negative swing, low-frequency, contributes small/neutral or slightly negative SHAP values.

Feature 2 (mid segment, t≈39–78): dominant discriminative feature — a trough-to-peak slow rise (t≈52: ≈ -0.9 → t≈70: ≈ +2.6). Manifestation: largest amplitude change, smooth single-peaked shape, concentrated low-frequency energy in STFT and strongest positive SHAP (primary basis for classification).

Feature 3 (late-mid segment, t≈78–117): decline from the mid peak into another negative region culminating near t≈117 (≈ -1.85). Manifestation: a symmetric-looking downward swing after the peak; contributes neutral-to-negative SHAP depending on exact timing.

Feature 4 (end segment, t≈117–143): recovery to moderate positive values (≈ -1.85 up to ≈ +1.2). Manifestation: smaller-amplitude smooth rise with weaker low-frequency energy and mild positive SHAP — supportive but not decisive.

Temporal dependence and combination: the time series shows slow oscillatory structure with roughly 40–50 time-step spacing between consecutive extrema (t≈25 trough → t≈70 peak → t≈117 trough). The classifier weights the mid large-amplitude, low-frequency bump most heavily; negative troughs elsewhere reduce confidence but are overridden when the central bump is present. Overall, classification arises from the presence, amplitude, and low-frequency character of the central bulge relative to surrounding troughs.
Overall feature pattern of Sample 90 (Label 4, Harrier):

Feature A (t≈0–18): Strong initial downward transient — rapid decline from ~+1.0 to ~−1.9 (sharp negative trough). Manifestation: High amplitude negative deflection, relatively steep slope; STFT indicates low-frequency content. Role: secondary positive evidence (small positive SHAP) likely representing an identifying indentation or wing feature.

Feature B (t≈39–70): Dominant broad positive hump — slow rise from ~+0.5 to peak ≈+2.6 (≈t=65) then faster descent. Manifestation: Large-amplitude, low-frequency, asymmetric peak (rise ≈20 steps, fall ≈10–15 steps). Role: primary class-determining feature (strong positive SHAP concentrated at lowest frequency bins in this time window).

Feature C (t≈70–105): Mid-to-late negative valley — descent through zero to ~−1.8 around t≈104–110. Manifestation: Moderate-amplitude negative trough with smoother transition; SHAP mostly neutral or slightly negative. Role: not strongly supportive; provides contrast to the main hump which the model prioritizes.

Feature D (t≈117–143): Late upward recovery — moderate rise from ~−1.8 to ~+1.0 with some volatility. Manifestation: Smaller-scale positive trend with higher volatility than the main hump; low-frequency energy present. Role: secondary supporting cue (small positive SHAP), reinforcing overall shape pattern.

Temporal dependence and combination: The classifier appears to use a combination of large-scale, low-frequency shape components in particular temporal order — an early trough, a dominant central hump, then a following trough and a late recovery. The asymmetric main hump (slow rise, faster fall) combined with the initial trough and final recovery forms a composite contour signature the model associates with label 4. There is no strong periodic high-frequency oscillation; instead the signal is dominated by slow oscillatory behavior (large-scale waveform) whose relative amplitudes and asymmetries across time steps determine the classification.

feature: Observation 1 (time ~36–70): A broad, smooth positive hump is visible in the main plot between roughly time steps 36 and 70: the signal rises from about -0.9 at t≈36 to a local maximum ≈+0.8 near t≈55, then falls back toward ≈-0.5 by t≈70. The SHAP heatmap shows the strongest red (positive attribution) concentrated at the lowest frequency rows for this same time window. STFT: concentrated energy at very low frequencies (< ~0.05) during this interval. -> Implication: The classifier strongly uses this slow, high-amplitude, low-frequency upward-then-downward lobe as a positive indicator for the F-22 label. The shape (broad single-cycle oscillation) is a discriminative large-scale contour feature rather than a transient spike.

Observation 2 (time ~50–60 substructure): Within the larger hump above, the rise from t≈45 to t≈55 is relatively steep (~1.3 units increase over ~10 time steps) and the fall after the peak is somewhat slower. There is no high-frequency noise superimposed on the peak. SHAP red intensity is highest exactly over the rising-to-peak interval. STFT: dominated by the lowest frequency bins. -> Implication: The classifier weighs the asymmetric rise-to-peak substructure (a pronounced, relatively fast ascent into a broad peak) as especially indicative; the timing and slope of this ascent are important discriminative cues.

Observation 3 (time ~78–92): A second mid-sequence positive excursion is present from roughly t≈78 to t≈92, peaking around t≈88 near +0.6, preceded and followed by negative troughs. SHAP shows moderate red attribution at low frequencies here as well. STFT: low-frequency content persists, with a slightly broader band than the primary hump. -> Implication: Repeated low-frequency lobes (multiple broad oscillations) reinforce the classifier’s decision. The presence of successive broad positive lobes at these relative positions is treated as supportive evidence for the class.

Observation 4 (time ~100–118): A broader negative-to-positive-to-negative cycle occurs roughly between t≈96 and t≈118: the signal climbs from ~-0.4 at t≈96 to a modest peak near t≈104 (≈+0.1) then falls to a deeper trough ≈-1.5 near t≈118. The SHAP heatmap shows a smaller but distinct red patch at low frequencies centered near the rising portion close to t≈104. STFT: a localized increase of low-frequency power at this time. -> Implication: The classifier grants positive attribution to the rising flank and early peak of this cycle — it is likely using the relative timing and presence of this mid-late positive excursion (even if small) as part of the overall pattern for F-22.

Observation 5 (time edges ~0 and ~143): Large positive values at the sequence edges (starting value ≈+2.8 at t=0 and ending value ≈+2.7 at t≈143) are visible in the time series. STFT shows strong low-frequency content at the two ends; SHAP shows little red at very highest-frequency rows but some low-frequency positive attribution near the ends. -> Implication: The high amplitudes at the sequence boundaries provide supportive but not sole evidence; the classifier places primary weight on the mid-sequence low-frequency oscillatory motifs, but edge amplitude patterns also contribute positively.

Observation 6 (localized volatility around t≈62–68): Around t≈62–68 there is a small cluster of short wiggles / very small high-frequency variations (tiny rapid up/down ticks) superimposed on the descending flank after the main peak. SHAP heatmap shows little to no red at higher-frequency rows for these times. STFT: higher-frequency bins show only weak energy here. -> Implication: High-frequency micro-variations are not positively attributed; the classifier focuses on low-frequency structure, so small jitter is likely ignored or neutral in labeling.

Observation 7 (frequency-domain summary): Across the red-attributed regions, SHAP highlights primarily the lowest frequency bands (the two lowest rows), while higher frequencies are near-white. STFT confirms that most signal energy relevant to classification is concentrated below ~0.05 (normalized frequency). -> Implication: The discriminative features for this sample are large-scale, slow-varying contour components (broad lobes/undulations) rather than rapid oscillations or transient spikes. The model’s decision for label 5 relies on these slow, spatially-extended shape signatures.
pattern: The feature pattern of Sample 21 (Label 5, F-22) is: Dominant low-frequency multi-lobe structure + localized asymmetric rises (occurrence times and manifestations) as follows:

Feature A (t≈36–70) — Primary discriminative lobe: a large amplitude, low-frequency positive hump (rise from ≈-0.9 to ≈+0.8, then fall) centered ≈t=55; shape = broad single-cycle oscillation with a steeper rise than fall. This is the strongest positively attributed element by SHAP and coincides with strong STFT energy at the lowest frequencies.
Feature B (t≈78–92) — Secondary positive lobe: a smaller broad hump (peak ≈+0.6) that repeats the low-frequency pattern and strengthens time-dependence (the sample shows serial broad oscillations).

Feature C (t≈96–118) — Late-cycle rise & deep trough: a modest positive excursion around t≈100–105 that the model treats positively, followed by a deeper negative trough near t≈118; this sequence of up/down contributes to the overall signature.
Feature D (sequence edges t≈0 and t≈143) — Very large endpoint amplitudes (≈+2.8) that provide additional positive support but are secondary to mid-sequence low-frequency motifs.

Temporal dependence and combination: the classifier appears to require a combination of these low-frequency lobes at specific relative positions (primary mid-sequence hump + one or two supporting lobes later) — i.e., the presence, relative timing, amplitude and asymmetric rise/fall substructure together form the class-specific pattern. High-frequency jitter is negligible for classification.

feature: Observation: Strong positive SHAP mass concentrated at the very-low-frequency band (closest to 0 Hz) spanning roughly time steps 13 → 104 (with particularly intense contribution around 65 → 91). Corresponding plot manifestation: a sequence of broad, smooth oscillations (large-scale envelope) with peaks ~+0.8 and troughs ~-1.3 across that interval. -> Implication: The classifier strongly favors the slow, large-scale contour variations (low-frequency envelope) present across this middle region. In contour terms, broad, smooth shape undulations (rather than high-frequency details) are a positive signature for label 6 (F-15).

Observation: At the start (≈ time 0 → 13) the series has a large positive offset (peak ≈ +2.8 → +3.0) and then a steady decline to near 0; STFT shows dominant energy at very low frequency there and SHAP is positive. -> Implication: A pronounced leading positive excursion (a large baseline/bulge) in the early portion contributes positively to the classification — the model uses large-scale positive offsets (global bulges) as evidence toward F-15.

Observation: In the early-to-mid trough region (≈ time 13 → 26) the signal descends into a deep trough (min ≈ -1.3 to -1.4) with moderate slope and low-frequency power; SHAP in low-frequency rows is positive. -> Implication: A prominent, broad trough (smooth negative excursion) is also a positive cue. The model treats large, smooth troughs (wide concavities in the contour) as characteristic of the class.

Observation: Between ≈ 52 → 78 the plot contains two relatively smooth positive pulses (peaks near 65 and 78, ~+0.6–+0.8) separated by a modest dip; STFT shows some mid-frequency energy emerging here, and SHAP remains positive at the lowest frequencies while showing small negative values at mid-frequency in nearby times. -> Implication: The presence of twin, broad peaks (low-frequency) contributes positively, but sharper components (midsize / mid-frequency oscillations) in the same window slightly reduce the class score. The classifier prefers the smooth twin-peak substructure rather than sharper, higher-frequency ripples.

Observation: From ≈ 78 → 104 there is a steep downward transition from a peak (~+0.8) to a deep trough (~-1.3) — this segment shows elevated mid-frequency energy in the STFT and clear blue (negative) SHAP at those mid-frequency rows. -> Implication: Rapid, higher-frequency transitions and sharper edges in this window are negative evidence for label 6. The model penalizes abrupt changes (local high-frequency content), indicating that excessively sharp contour features are atypical for the F-15 signature.

Observation: Final segment (≈ 130 → 143) displays a pronounced, fast rise from ~+0.3 to ~+2.8 (large positive endpoint) with low-frequency dominance and modest positive SHAP there. -> Implication: A large-scale terminal bulge (strong low-frequency positive excursion at the end) increases the model's confidence in F-15 — large-scale positive endpoint structure is supportive of the label.

Observation: Across most of the series the STFT energy is concentrated at the lowest frequency bins (global / DC-like components); SHAP highlights those same low-frequency bins positively, while mid-frequency bands (≈0.08–0.12 Hz region in STFT) carry occasional negative SHAP around times ~70–95. -> Implication: The classifier’s decision is driven mainly by global shape (very low-frequency) features; localized mid-frequency components act as detractors. Thus, the model is effectively distinguishing coarse contour shape vs. fine texture.

Observation: Volatility pattern — cycles are generally smooth and low-volatility (gentle slopes) except for localized steep transitions (notably around 78 → 104 and the final rise). Those steep transitions line up with mid-frequency energy and negative SHAP patches. -> Implication: Smooth, low-volatility oscillatory cycles are indicative of the class, while transient high-volatility events reduce the class likelihood.
pattern: The feature pattern of Sample 50 is: Dominant low-frequency baseline + slow oscillatory envelope (global structure) present across nearly the whole time series (most energy at very-low-frequency bins). Manifestation: repeated broad peaks and troughs approximately every ~20–35 time steps (e.g., trough near 20, peaks near 65 and 78, trough near 100, final rise near 143).

Superimposed on that baseline are a few localized sharper transitions (notably ≈78→104 where the series drops rapidly, and the final climb 130→143). These create mid-frequency bursts in the STFT but are treated as negative evidence by the classifier (blue SHAP at mid-frequency).

Time-series dependence: the sequence exhibits slowly varying periodic-like behavior (low-frequency cycles) with consistent phase progression — the large-scale oscillation at earlier times continues into middle and later times, indicating a coherent global contour signature rather than isolated spikes. The classifier leverages this temporal consistency of low-frequency components across multiple windows to form a stable positive attribution.

Summary interpretation for classification: the model favors broad, smooth, low-frequency contour structures (wide peaks/troughs and large endpoint bulges) found in multiple contiguous windows; intermittent high-frequency, abrupt variations reduce the score. This combination (persistent low-frequency envelope + relatively few high-frequency transients) is the pattern that leads the model to assign label 6 (F-15).

feature: Observation: Strong red SHAP block concentrated at the lowest frequency rows (near 0.0–0.05 Hz) spanning roughly time steps 39 through 91 (the largest contiguous red patch in the heatmap). -> Implication: The model relied heavily on slow / low-frequency content in the mid segment of the contour/time series to push the prediction toward class 1 (Eurofighter). This means broad, slowly-varying shape components (large-scale curvature or broad lobes) in that angular/time window were treated as positive evidence for the predicted class.

Observation: In the raw time series, the same time window (≈ t=39–91) contains two clear upward excursions (local maxima near t≈48 with amplitude ≈ +0.9–1.0 and near t≈74 with amplitude ≈ +1.1–1.3) separated by intermediate troughs (local minima near t≈56–60 at ≈ -0.7 to -0.9, and another dip near t≈85–92 at ≈ -0.6 to -0.8). -> Implication: The SHAP-identified positive contribution corresponds to a pattern of broad, alternating peak–trough–peak (two main lobes) in the middle of the contour. The classifier appears to treat the presence and spacing of those broad peaks as a discriminative signature aligned with class 1.

Observation: Change rates across those rises are moderate and sustained: e.g., from t≈39 (≈ -0.6) to t≈48 (≈ +1.0) is an approximate rise of ~+1.6 over ~9 time steps (~+0.14 per step); from the trough at t≈56 (≈ -0.8) to the second peak at t≈74 (≈ +1.2) is ~+2.0 over ~18 steps (~+0.11 per step). These are gentle/low-frequency slopes rather than abrupt spikes. -> Implication: The model's positive attribution correlates with slow, sustained changes rather than high-frequency, sharp edges — consistent with the STFT showing energy concentrated at very low frequencies in this time band.

Observation: The STFT image shows that during t≈39–91 the energy is concentrated in the lowest frequency bins (brightest colors at the bottom of the spectrogram in that time range) while mid and higher frequency bands are weak. -> Implication: The positive SHAP values reflect genuine low-frequency structure (broad shape features), not transient high-frequency noise. The model is therefore basing its decision on global shape curvature in the mid-portion of the sequence.

Observation: There are other parts of the series with large amplitude (start t≈0 with value ≈ +2.4 and end t≈143 with value ≈ +2.3) that are not strongly red in the SHAP heatmap. -> Implication: The classifier is not giving those large end amplitudes strong positive weight for class 1; instead it focuses on the mid-segment low-frequency pattern. This suggests the learned decision boundary emphasizes mid-window broad lobes over absolute amplitude extremes when assigning class 1 scores.

Observation: Small-scale oscillatory structure and higher-frequency content (visible as finer wiggles in the raw trace and faint STFT bands above ~0.05 Hz) correspond to near-white / neutral or slightly blue regions in the SHAP heatmap. -> Implication: Higher-frequency / fine-detail features (sharp corners or small fins in the contour) are either neutral or negatively weighted for class 1, so absence of discriminative high-frequency signatures may have reduced evidence for the true class (Mirage) and allowed the mid-window low-frequency pattern to dominate the prediction.
pattern: The feature pattern of Sample 61 (true label: 0) is: Broad low-frequency mid-window signature (occurrence t≈39–91) (manifestation: two sustained broad peaks at ≈t=48 and ≈t=74 with intermediate troughs; amplitude range in this window ≈ -0.9 to +1.3; moderate slopes ≈ 0.11–0.14 units/step) (red in SHAP → positive contributor) (model result: drives prediction toward class 1) + Large endpoint amplitudes (occurrence t≈0 and t≈143) (manifestation: single large positive values ≈+2.3–2.4) (heatmap mostly neutral/weak → not used strongly) (model result: not decisive) + High-frequency fine structure (occurrence scattered across series) (manifestation: small wiggles and sharper changes) (heatmap neutral/blue → weakly negative or neutral) (model result: not used to support class 1).

Overall interpretation: The classifier gives dominant positive weight to slow, broad contour features in the mid angular/time band (low STFT frequencies). Those features match patterns the model associates with Eurofighter (predicted label 1), overpowering endpoint amplitude cues and any high-frequency fine-detail cues that might indicate the true class (Mirage). The SHAP map and STFT together show that the decisive evidence is low-frequency, mid-series structure rather than abrupt or end-of-series magnitude.

feature: Observation (t ≈ 60–76): A pronounced positive peak develops from about 0.4 up to ~+1.7 over ≈10–15 time steps (rise rate ~+0.09–+0.15 units/step), reaching a local maximum near t≈70–73. Volatility low during the rise (smooth monotonic increase) and the peak is broad (plateau-like for a few steps). STFT: energy concentrated at the lowest frequency band during this interval (strong low-frequency content). SHAP: this same time × low-frequency region is strongly red -> Implication: the model attributes this large, slow positive bulge heavily in favor of the predicted class (label 0). Because it is a low-frequency, shape-level feature (a broad top-side bulge in the contour), the model interprets it as a strong cue for its chosen class.

Observation (t ≈ 76–86): Immediately following the peak the series falls rapidly from ~+1.7 down to around -0.6 across ≈8–12 steps (fall rate roughly -0.18 to -0.3 units/step). This is a steep downward transition (high local change rate) producing a peak-to-valley substructure (sharp descent). STFT: still dominated by low-frequency power (the transition is slow compared with high-frequency noise). SHAP: this time window (low-frequency band) also appears red -> Implication: the model treats the peak+rapid descent sequence (the particular peak-to-valley shape) as supportive evidence for the predicted label. The combination of the preceding broad peak and the following steep fall forms a distinctive shape-level motif that the classifier uses to push the decision toward label 0.

Observation (t ≈ 88–96): A secondary, smaller positive excursion occurs (rise from ~-0.6 up to ~+0.8 around t≈92, then declines). Amplitude here is moderate compared with the main peak. STFT: increased low-frequency magnitude again in this window. SHAP: low-to-mid low-frequency cells at these times are red -> Implication: the model further credits these secondary slow oscillations as positive evidence for its predicted class, reinforcing the decision produced by the main peak region.

Observation (t ≈ 104–120): A deep negative trough is present, centered ≈116 with amplitude ≈ -1.6 to -1.8 (a broad valley spanning ≈104–120). The descent into the trough is fairly smooth and the trough is wide (low volatility inside the trough). STFT: low-frequency energy remains the dominant component. SHAP: low-frequency cells in this time range are strongly red (positive attribution for the model’s predicted class) -> Implication: unexpectedly, this large negative valley is also being used by the model as evidence for label 0. That indicates the model learned that the particular pattern of a broad negative valley at this location correlates with the predicted class in training data, even though visually it is an opposite-sign feature compared with the positive peak earlier.

Observation (t ≈ 128–143): A pronounced final rise occurs from about -1.0 up to the global maximum ≈+2.4 at the last timestep (large positive swing, steep positive slope in the last ≈15 steps). STFT: concentrated low-frequency energy for that interval as well. SHAP: low-frequency cells near the end are red (positive attribution) -> Implication: the model treats the final large upward swing and strong end-level positive amplitude as another decisive cue for the predicted class. The cumulative effect of multiple low-frequency, large-amplitude shape features (peak, trough, final rise) produces a net strong push toward label 0.

Observation (t ≈ 10–18): Small negative SHAP (blue) activity at low frequencies aligns with a moderate downward portion of the series (the curve descends through zero into negative values here). STFT: modest low-frequency energy. SHAP: blue -> Implication: this segment slightly opposes the model's chosen class (reduces logit for label 0) and would favor alternative classes (including the true label 1). However, its magnitude is smaller than the aggregated red contributions later, so it is insufficient to flip the outcome.

Observation (Frequency-specific note): Across the red regions, STFT shows the majority of signal power lies in the lowest frequency bins (very slow oscillatory / shape-level components), not in higher-frequency bands. SHAP red cells co-locate with these low-frequency bands -> Implication: the model relies primarily on coarse, global shape/low-frequency features (broad peaks and troughs and their locations) rather than high-frequency fine-detail features when producing its prediction.
pattern: The feature pattern of this sample (true label: 1) is: Large low-frequency shape components at multiple distinct times that together push the model to predict label 0 (predicted = 0, logits for label0=3.808, label1=3.512). Specifically:
Feature A (t ≈ 60–76): Broad positive peak (amplitude +0.4 → +1.7) (red) (SHAP red at low-frequency) (supports predicted class 0) +
Feature B (t ≈ 76–86): Immediate steep fall from that peak to a negative zone (peak→valley substructure, high change rate) (red) (SHAP red at low-frequency) (reinforces predicted class 0) +
Feature C (t ≈ 88–96): Secondary positive excursion (moderate amplitude) (red) (SHAP red) (additional supporting evidence) +
Feature D (t ≈ 104–120): Broad negative trough (amplitude ≈ -1.6) (red) (SHAP red) (model treats this valley as positive evidence for its label) +
Feature E (t ≈ 128–143): Final strong upward swing to the global maximum (~+2.4) (red) (SHAP red) (strongly supports predicted class 0).
Counteracting Feature (t ≈ 10–18): Small low-frequency negative segment (blue) (SHAP blue) (opposes label 0, slightly supports other classes including the true label 1).

Overall interpretation: The model heavily weights slow, global contour-like motifs (broad peaks/troughs and their timing) localized at multiple time ranges. These low-frequency motifs collectively yield a higher score for label 0 than label 1 (difference in logits ≈0.296), producing a misclassification of a sample that actually belongs to label 1. The STFT confirms that the influential components are dominantly low-frequency (shape-level) rather than high-frequency detail, suggesting the classifier relies on coarse silhouette-like cues; if Eurofighter-specific distinguishing cues are encoded at higher frequencies or in subtler spatial substructures, they are underweighted by the model, causing the error.
